title: You Didn't Opt In—You Can Still Opt Out
summary: A practical guide to reclaiming digital sovereignty through simple, actionable steps. Exposes how convenience has become a currency we spend without thinking, and offers concrete tools to stop feeding systems that treat you like a product.

Communication.summary: Replace extractive digital tools with privacy-respecting alternatives that serve you, not platforms.

level0: Switch your browser to Brave or Firefox
Download Signal and tell one friend
Change your search engine to DuckDuckGo
Audit one app's permissions on your phone
level1: Create your first email alias with Proton Mail
Set up unique passwords for each login
Review and limit app tracking permissions
Start using Signal for sensitive conversations
level2: Migrate from Gmail to Proton Mail completely
Set up anonymous logins for all new services
Use VPN for browsing and data protection
level3: Help friends and family implement digital sovereignty tools

Knowledge.summary: Understand how digital surveillance works and why privacy-by-design matters for personal sovereignty.

level0: Understand that you didn't opt into surveillance—it was imposed
Learn how 'convenience' often means giving up control
level1: Study how data collection and selling actually works
level2: Understand the broader implications of digital surveillance on democracy
Learn about alternative digital ecosystems and decentralized tools
level3: Develop expertise in digital security and privacy
Understand the economic models behind surveillance capitalism

Narrative.summary: Shift from 'convenience culture' to understanding digital tools as either liberation or extraction.

resources.label: 7 Steps to Quietly Exit a System

level0: Recognize that 'the coup already happened' through data control
Understand you're 'the designer of your experience,' not a passive user
level1: Learn to see convenience as a currency you can choose to spend or save
Understand that digital disobedience is necessary resistance
level2: Frame privacy tools as sovereignty tools, not paranoia
See yourself as walking away from extraction, toward liberation
level3: Help others understand digital sovereignty as part of broader system exit
Connect digital privacy to community resilience and mutual aid

Power.summary: Reclaim control over your digital life and data as a form of personal sovereignty.

level0: Stop clicking 'accept' without reading what you're agreeing to
Take one small action this week to reclaim digital control
level1: Delete or deactivate accounts you don't need
Stop feeding systems that treat you like a product
Choose one major platform to replace with a privacy-respecting alternative
level2: Build redundant systems that don't depend on Big Tech
Create multiple lines of digital defense and privacy
Develop skills to help others reclaim digital sovereignty
level3: Achieve comprehensive digital independence from surveillance systems
Support and fund privacy-respecting technology development
Build local networks that use sovereign digital tools
